awd_titl_txt: In-situ Observtion of Annealing Behaviors of Bulk Metallic Polycrystals
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Polycrystals are ubiquitous materials that serve in extreme and mundane environments, ranging from nuclear reactors and turbine blades to structural supports and transportation infrastructure. Until recently, it has not been possible to spatially resolve relevant structural details deep inside polycrystalline materials as they evolve in response to, for example, thermal annealing. In this project focused high energy x-rays generated at the Advanced Photon Source at the Argonne National Laboratory will be used in combination with the National Science Foundation's TeraGrid supercomputer network to non-destructively measure and reconstruct the crystallographic orientation field of polycrystals in three dimensions. In well-ordered materials, crystalline grain ensembles will be observed as they evolve during annealing; both statistical and local information will be extracted from large microstructure data sets. In materials with significant defect contents, it will be possible to measure orientation gradients within grains and to watch defect structures move and evolve as the material reaches a lower energy, more ordered state. Work under this grant will advance understanding of how polycrystalline materials respond to high temperatures. The results will be used to develop improved understanding of previously hidden phenomena with the goal of establishing validated models with predictive power.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Because polycrystals are so broadly used in industrial, energy, and defense systems, the potential economic and energy impact of improved basic scientific understanding of how polycrystalline microstructures evolve during annealing can be huge. The experiments in this project will use a Department of Energy national user facility (the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory, one of the world's most powerful x-ray sources) while the analysis of data will involve the National Science Foundation's TeraGrid supercomputer network. The resulting data will provide a unique look at the quantities that are relevant for building theories of how materials behave. A major objective of the research is to apply the understanding gained to the development of materials with improved properties. Graduate and undergraduate students, working with faculty and post-doctoral researchers from science, mathematics and engineering departments, will be mentored. They will become skilled in x-ray science that can be applied to many materials problems and will experience the high-performance computing world. The broad impact of the experimental program will be substantially increased through interactions with the modeling community.

Polycrystals are ubiquitous materials that serve in extreme and mundane environments -- from nuclear reactors and turbine blades to structural supports and transportation infrastructure. Critical properties emerge from a complex hierarchy of structures and interactions that range from the nano-scale to the macroscopic and reliability is crucial for advanced technologies and for public safety. Improved properties promise the possibility of doing more with less and, thus, of reducing energy and environmental impacts; with their broad range of applications, even incremental improvements will have a significant economic impact.  Recently have we developed the ability to observe internal structural evolution using a new form of "x-ray vision." Work under this grant represents some of the first and most extensive observations of internal structural evolution yet performed. The work advances basic knowledge of how this complex and important class of materials responds to external stimuli.

By studying the thermal responses of polycrystals using a unique new synchrotron based three dimensional x-ray characterization technique, High Energy X-ray Diffraction Microscopy (HEDM), users can "see" deep inside materials. The technique was developed under prior National Science Foundation and Department of Energy support; it is now being applied by a broad materials community to study many technologically important materials responses. The thermal responses we studied relate to the development and coarsening of crystalline "grains" which takes place at elevated temperatures. This process occurs during materials processing as well as in a variety of application environments and is linked to significant changes in application critical macroscopic properties.

We have studied three distinct metals, aluminum, nickel, and iron in measurements performed at the Advanced Photon Source (APS) synchrotron at Argonne National Laboratory. In the aluminum sample, we were able to watch as new grains appeared and were able to see that they appeared specifically within highly deformed sub-volumes of the sample. We also observed the reduction in defect content within existing grains as the sample was annealed.  In the nickel and iron samples, we began with low defect content grains; annealing these grains generally leads to small grains being consumed by large grains resulting in coarsening of the structure. The motions of interfaces between grains (grain boundaries) are expected to depend on a five parameter specification of the type or "character" of each boundary. Our measurements of thousands of grains and their boundary motions are being used to test theories of these motions.

In the course of this work, we have developed new algorithms for estimating grain boundary character and for tracking boundary motions. Both of these algorithms use the mathematics of optimization and can find applications to other similar data sets and in other realms of science, even reaching into medical imaging, for example.

Work supported by this grant has had broad impact both within the materials research community concerned with polycrystalline materials and in the more general scientific community. Graduate students (two receiving primary support for thesis work, three additional receiving partial support during work on the project) are trained in high performance computing, materials properties and processes, synchrotron radiation x-ray studies, presentation skills, and scientific writing. The graduate students have benefited from extensive collaborations. At CMU, we interact with faculty and students in Materials Science and Engineering and Physics, as well as in the Mathematical Sciences Department.
